instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Came in with a significant coffee spill around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

Gave it an ultrasonic clean as it was still sticky.

<RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> were burnt out. Replaced them, got green light but n fan spin. A few minutes later <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> burnt out. Replaced it again and looked around for a short on the G3H lines but couldn't find anything.

Now I get no green light but <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> measure correct. But the voltage on <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is somewhere around 0.7v and always moving. Diode mode on <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is about 0.130.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>     = 8.20 - 8.50.
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>   = 2.66 - moving


Edit: Any idea why the battery interface was designed the way it was for this model? Seems overly complicated for almost zero benefit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: Voltage on pin 3 of <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>? Resistance to GND on 3V42?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: I would say dead <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> or one of the resistors/caps around it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> already, will check all resistors again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: Then inject 3V42 from external PSU and check current draw. Could be a half fried SMC too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Thought about what you said; I so removed and re-replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and BOOM!

We got fan spin! :)




Edit: After a couple reboots the battery showed 100% then 0 then an X. :(

Runs of battery just won't start off it or see it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> is 0.474
pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> is 0.572

Reseated everything; and now I get displayed 0% with no adapter and 100% with the adapter. Then after a minute or so it shows like a service battery icon.

But it runs off the battery fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: Diode mode has too much difference. Could be crap under SMC/dead SMC/<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Re measuring this morning I get;

pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> is 0.474
pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> is 0.477

Could it be heat related. It seems I can get 0% and 100% then eventually I get no battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message:
Customer took the laptop without a battery as they needed it for work.

Has come back now as it won't boot and the fans run high.

ASD EFI Reports;

SMC IO failed:
TA0P - Ambient Air Sensor,
TA1P - DC-IN Proximity Airflow,
TC0P - CPU Proximity,
TM0P - DDR3 Proximity and
TW0P - AirPort Proximity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No green light.
threads.message: As I said, crap under SMC.
